:fire: This class was not used anymore

Removed translations not needed and removed page variables for these translations. Updated ProjectSynchronizationSettings component to use SyncFrequencySelect component for selecting sync frequency

Merge pull request #801 from phac-nml/FIX-remoate-oath-CREATE_REMOTE_PROJECT

Fix remoate oath create remote project
Added test for remote project synchronization settings page
Moved ajax methods to new controller. Updated sync mapping method to accept a RemoteProjectSettingsUpdateRequest dto instead of individual params.
Removed redundant setting of base url
Removed br tags, updated to use ant design title, removed redudnant === true when checking if forceSync is set

Created new UIRemoteProjectService and refactored code from ProjectSettingsRemoteAjaxController into this service to clean up controller. Updated translation keys to preface with server.ProjectRemote which are returned for that component. Updated controller methods to return ResponseEntity<DTOTYYPE> and uiremoteprojectservice to return objects rather than a map
Updated to catch an exception and return bad request http status

Added tests for uiremoteprojectservice. Updated getProjectRemoteSettings method to catch an error. Updated remote-projects.js api calls to catch and throw errors that the component can catch and display

timeline.bodyText: This should not need a @RestController mapping.  Just @Controller right?
timeline.author: tom114

replies.bodyText: No this is completely intentional.  "@RestController is a specialized version of the controller. It includes the @controller and @responsebody annotations and as a result, simplifies the controller implementation" from https://www.baeldung.com/spring-controller-vs-restcontroller This works since this is a purely AJAX controller.
replies.author: joshsadam

timeline.bodyText: There's enough of these dto classes to make a sub package for the Remote API stuff.  That package is getting messy.
timeline.author: tom114

timeline.bodyText: Again, this should likely be a @Controller
timeline.author: tom114

timeline.bodyText: Do we need 2 separate classes for this?  It's a combined 3 methods between this class and the Ajax controller.
timeline.author: tom114

replies.bodyText: @deepsidhu85  and I have been working really hard at keeping all the controllers really lean and only handling what their job is.  A @controller's job is to return a view and that's it, a @RestController is to handle an ajax request.  If either of those those actually need some data (which is basically always for the ajax controllers), they can reach out to a specifically designed service.  That way it is easy to know where to go to find/fix a problem.  It keeps the controllers nice and lean and easy to read and way easier to test.
replies.author: joshsadam

timeline.bodyText: What's the point of this class?  It's just re-wrapping other service methods.  Every method is only called from one place.  Why not just have the functionality in those places?
timeline.author: tom114

timeline.bodyText: Same deal with this class.  These 2 methods are only used in one place.  Why add an extra class?
timeline.author: tom114

replies.bodyText: Same deal here, please see above response.
replies.author: joshsadam

timeline.author: tom114

timeline.bodyText: Remove commented code if its not needed, or redo method if it is needed
